content.raw:
In the 2.3.1 update, the viscous damping coefficients for following joints were increased from 0.1 to 10:

* back_lbz
* back_mby
* back_ubx
* l_leg_uhz
* l_leg_mhx
* l_leg_lhy
* r_leg_uhz
* r_leg_mhx
* r_leg_lhy

These damping coefficients are unrealistic and break our current controller. The original 0.1 values are much closer to what you would get on a real robot, and much more workable.

Could I ask what the reason was for increasing these damping coefficients in the first place? If it was to increase simulation stability, these two issues could be related:
https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/634/joint-velocity-limit-causes-significant
#!/osrf/sandia-hand/issue/3/damping-extremely-large

This last issue relates increasing damping to not hitting joint velocity limits, which we think are the source of the simulation instability.
content.html:
In the 2.3.1 update, the viscous damping coefficients for following joints were increased from 0.1 to 10:

  • back_lbz
  • back_mby
  • back_ubx
  • l_leg_uhz
  • l_leg_mhx
  • l_leg_lhy
  • r_leg_uhz
  • r_leg_mhx
  • r_leg_lhy

These damping coefficients are unrealistic and break our current controller. The original 0.1 values are much closer to what you would get on a real robot, and much more workable.

Could I ask what the reason was for increasing these damping coefficients in the first place? If it was to increase simulation stability, these two issues could be related: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/634/joint-velocity-limit-causes-significant #!/osrf/sandia-hand/issue/3/damping-extremely-large

This last issue relates increasing damping to not hitting joint velocity limits, which we think are the source of the simulation instability.
